newsitem.title: LITHUANIA: BOURSE HOPES FOR MORE FOREIGN INTEREST.
newsitem.headline: BOURSE HOPES FOR MORE FOREIGN INTEREST.

text.p: Lithuania's Stock Exchange hopes a May 15-16 conference in Vilnius will generate more foreign interest in the bourse, which has been struggling to regain the momentum it had during a bull run in January.

"It's the first possibility to meet with foreign investors and to give them a full introduction to the Lithuanian securities market," said Rimantas Busila, General Director of the National Stock Exchange of Lithuania.
Brokers are also hoping that the conference will attract more foreign money into the local market.
"Any kind of conference is important," said Tomas Andrejauskas, a broker with Suprema. "That's marketing."
But Andrejauskas said any new interest resulting from the conference would not be seen quickly.
"I wouldn't say it will affect the market within a week... perhaps in half a year," Andrejauskas said.
"We hope that it will be helpful because there are no institutional investors in Lithuania," said Grazina Bachiuliene, a broker with Vilfima.
"There are no pension funds in Lithuania, and there are very few insurance companies...and they are interested in very safe investments," she said.
"In Lithuania, it's a new kind of investment, and it's difficult to start when you see the prices going down," Bachiuliene added.
Share prices have been falling steadily, with a few hicups, since their brief but spectacular rise in January, when they soared to record highs.
But dealers and the bourse hope that long-term foreign investors will be lured by bargain prices, improved financial results, increased transparency, and the upcoming sale of key state assets.
